{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{BLP sources|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Shakil Afridi | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1962}} | birth_place = Malikdinkhel, [[Bara, FATA|Bara]], [[Khyber Agency]], [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas|FATA]], Pakistan | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Pakistan]] | field = | work_institution = | alma_mater = [[Khyber Medical College]] | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | occupation = Physician | prizes = | known = Helped [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] run fake Hepatitis B [[Vaccination schedule|vaccine program]]<ref name=Animesh>{{cite web|last1=Roul|first1=Animesh|date=27 August 2014|title=The Pakistani Taliban's Campaign Against Polio Vaccination|url=https://www.ctc.usma.edu/posts/the-pakistani-talibans-campaign-against-polio-vaccination|website=Combatting Terrorism Center at West Point|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> ([[Abbottabad]], Pakistan) to confirm [[Osama bin Laden]]'s presence through [[DNA]] samples. }}
'''Shakil Afridi''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|شکیل آفریدی}}}}), or '''Shakeel Afridi''', is a [[Pakistanis|Pakistani]] physician who helped the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] run a fake hepatitis [[Vaccination schedule|vaccine program]]<ref name=Animesh/> in [[Abbottabad]], [[Pakistan]], to confirm [[Osama bin Laden]]'s presence in the city by obtaining [[DNA]] samples.<ref name="BBC20111006">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-15206639|title=Bin Laden death: 'CIA doctor' accused of treason|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=6 October 2011|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> Details of his activities emerged during the Pakistani investigation of the [[Death of Osama bin Laden|deadly raid]] on bin Laden's residence.<ref>{{cite web|author=Saeed Shah|date=11 July 2011|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2011/07/11/117445/pakistan-holds-doctor-who-tried.html#storylink=misearch#storylink=cpy|title=Pakistan holds doctor who tried to collect bin Laden DNA|work=McClatchy DC|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> This account is disputed in a recent account of events which implies Afridi was implicated as a cover for the real CIA operative.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Killing of Osama bin Laden|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v37/n10/seymour-m-hersh/the-killing-of-osama-bin-laden|work=LRB|date=12 May 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510191921/http://www.lrb.co.uk/v37/n10/seymour-m-hersh/the-killing-of-osama-bin-laden|archivedate=10 May 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> Afridi was arrested at the [[Torkham|Torkham border crossing]] while trying to flee the country days after the raid.<ref name="NYT20111006">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/07/world/asia/pakistan-doctor-who-aided-cia-should-face-charges.html|title=Pakistan: Doctor Who Aided C.I.A. Should Face Charges, Panel Says|date=6 October 2011|agency=Associated Press|work=The New York Times|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> On 23 May 2012, he was sentenced to 33 years' imprisonment for [[treason]], initially believed to be in connection with the bin Laden raid, but later revealed to be due to alleged ties with a local Islamist warlord [[Mangal Bagh]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Reza Sayah|title=Pakistani doctor accused of helping U.S. gets 33 years in prison|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/05/23/world/asia/pakistan-bin-laden-doctor/index.html?hpt=hp_t1|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=23 May 2012|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="et20120530">{{cite news | url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/386265/dr-shakil-afridi-jailed-for-militant-links/ | title=Dr Shakil Afridi jailed for 'militant links' | work=The Express Tribune | date=30 May 2012 | agency=AFP | accessdate=31 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/pakistan/Pakistan-doctor-Shakil-Afridi-guilty-of-militancy-not-CIA-links/articleshow/13664227.cms | title=Pakistan doctor Shakil Afridi guilty of militancy, not CIA links | date=30 May 2012 | work=The Times of India}}</ref> Lawyers appealed against the verdict on 1 June 2012.<ref name="afp20120601">{{cite news | url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/387330/dr-shakil-afridi-appeals-conviction-charity/ | title=Dr Shakil Afridi appeals conviction: Charity | work=The Express Tribune | date=1 June 2012 | agency=AFP | accessdate=1 June 2012}}</ref> On 29 August 2013, his sentence was overturned and a retrial ordered.<ref name="Fox News">{{cite news|title=Pakistan overturns prison sentence for doctor who helped CIA get Bin Laden|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/06/30/pakistan-overturns-prison-sentence-for-doctor-who-helped-cia-get-usama-bin/|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=29 August 2013|date=29 August 2013}}</ref> In mid-November 2013, he was charged with murder in regard to the death of a patient he had treated eight years previously.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jibran Ahmed| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/22/us-pakistan-afridi-murder-idUSBRE9AL0F720131122 | work=Reuters | title=Pakistani doctor who helped U.S. find bin Laden charged with murder | date=22 November 2013|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref>
==Biography== Afridi comes from a humble background and in 1990 graduated from the [[Khyber Medical College]], Peshawar. He had been working as the doctor in-charge of Khyber Agency of the [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas]] of Pakistan. The doctor has a family. Considered an American hero by many who believe his actions were altruistic, Afridi is currently serving a 33-year sentence in a Pakistani jail, convicted of charges unrelated to his alleged CIA connections. Sentenced for supporting a Pakistani warlord, many of Afridi's supporters appear to have abandoned him at home and abroad, including his alleged U.S. supporters within the CIA and the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama Administration]].<ref name="at20120208">{{cite news | url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/NB08Df01.html | title=Pakistan snubs US over Osama informer | work=Asia Times Online | date=8 February 2012 | accessdate=3 June 2012 | author=Mir, Amir}}</ref> He is a native of [[Khyber Agency]].<ref>[http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2012%5C02%5C18%5Cstory_18-2-2012_pg3_6 ANALYSIS: Dr Shakil Afridi —Faruhat Taj]</ref> In July 2011, Afridi was described as being in his late 40s. There are numerous online petitions and web pages dedicated to freeing him, such as the "Free Dr. Shakil Afridi NOW" Facebook page with over 400 likes.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/12/us-pressures-islamabad-cia-doctor |title=US pressures Islamabad to free doctor who helped CIA track down Bin Laden |author=Saeed Shah |date=12 July 2011 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] }}</ref>
==Pakistan's accusations of Afridi== Afridi was the chief surgeon at [[Jamrud]] Hospital in Pakistan's northwestern Khyber tribal region. His colleagues were suspicious of Afridi's absences, which he explained as "business" to attend to in Abbottabad. Afridi was accused of having taken a half-dozen [[World Health Organization]] cooler boxes without authorisation. The containers are for inoculation campaigns, but no immunisation drives were underway in Abbottabad or the Khyber Agency.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2012/02/05/the-pakistani-doctor-who-helped-the-cia-nail-bin-laden.html# |title=The Pakistani Doctor Who Helped the CIA Nail Bin Laden |access-date=6 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306141713/http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2012/02/05/the-pakistani-doctor-who-helped-the-cia-nail-bin-laden.html# |archive-date=6 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=12109&Cat=13 |title=Abbottabad Commission orders treason case against Dr Afridi|date=30 January 2012 |newspaper=The News International, Pakistan}}</ref>
On 6 October 2011, the Pakistani commission investigating bin Laden's death recommended that he be charged with "conspiracy against the state of Pakistan and high treason" on the basis of available evidence.<ref name="NYT20111006" /> Pakistan seized Afridi's assets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2012/02/24/shakeel-afridis-property-sealedsources.html|title=Shakeel Afridi's assets siezed{{sic|hide=y}}: sources|work=dawn.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226001416/http://www.dawn.com/2012/02/24/shakeel-afridis-property-sealedsources.html|archivedate=26 February 2012|deadurl=no|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> Afridi's residence was sealed by Pakistani authorities and his family moved to an undisclosed location.<ref>[http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2012\03\05\story_5-3-2012_pg7_7 Dr Shakeel Afridi’s residence sealed in Peshawar]</ref> The fifteen male and female health workers who assisted Afridi in the fake hepatitis vaccination program were also declared not fit for any future employment.<ref>[http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2012%5C03%5C26%5Cstory_26-3-2012_pg7_19 KP govt disqualifies Dr Shakil Afridi for job]</ref>
Pakistani investigators said in a July 2012 report that Afridi met 25 times with "foreign secret agents, received instructions and provided sensitive information to them."<ref name="wapo20120726">{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/pakistan-recounts-how-convicted-spy-helped-us-in-bin-laden-operation/2012/07/26/gJQAGyL1BX_story.html | title=Pakistan recounts in new report how doctor helped U.S. in bin Laden operation | work=The Washington Post | date=26 July 2012 | accessdate=27 July 2012 | author=Leiby, Richard}}</ref> According to Pakistani reports, Afridi told investigators that the charity [[Save the Children]] helped facilitate his meeting with U.S. intelligence agents although the charity denies the charge. The report alleges that Save the Children's Pakistan director introduced Afridi to a western woman in Islamabad and that Afridi and the woman met regularly afterwards.<ref name="guardian20120905">{{cite news | url=http://gu.com/p/3a8ct | title=Pakistan orders Save the Children foreign workers to leave |newspaper=The Guardian | date=5 September 2012 | accessdate=6 September 2012 | author=Boone, Jon}}</ref><ref>[http://uk.news.yahoo.com/pakistan-orders-expulsion-save-children-staff-105312846.html Save the Children foreign staff told to leave Pakistan]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-19500103|title=Save the Children foreign staff ordered out of Pakistan|work=BBC News}}</ref>
===Torture=== In an interview with [[Fox News]], Afridi described being routinely [[torture]]d by the Pakistani [[Inter-Services Intelligence]] (ISI) with cigarette burns and electric shocks while at ISI Headquarters at Abpara.<ref name="foxnews20120910">{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/09/10/exclusive-jailed-doc-who-helped-nail-bin-laden-warns-us-seen-as-pakistan-worst/ | title=EXCLUSIVE: Jailed doc who helped nail Bin Laden warns Pakistan sees U.S. as 'worst enemy' | work=foxnews.com | date=10 September 2012 | agency=FOX News Network | accessdate=11 September 2012 | author=Di Natale, Dominic}}</ref> Citing "very strict security," Afridi's lawyer told [[BBC News]] that he had doubts of the authenticity of the interview.<ref name="bbc20120911">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-19554551 | title=Bin Laden raid doctor Shakil Afridi speaks out | work=BBC News | date=11 September 2012 | accessdate=11 September 2012}}</ref> Di-Natale was blacklisted by Pakistan barring him from returning to the country and Fox News reporter/producer Sib Kaifee was grilled by the country's top intelligence agency and was forced to flee the country fearing reprisal.
Family members and a member of his legal counsel also stated Afridi had been tortured while in Pakistani custody during November 2012.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/12/11/hero-doctor-who-helped-nail-bin-laden-tortured-in-pakistani-prison-says-family/ | title=Hero doctor who helped nail Bin Laden tortured in Pakistani prison says family | date=11 December 2012 | agency=FOX | accessdate=12 December 2012 | work=Fox News}}</ref> [[Waad ur Rahman]], an ''[[The Express Tribune|Express Tribune]]'' blogger argues that through a fair trial, Afridi would also have a chance to defend why he did not disclose the location of bin Laden to Pakistani authorities. He said, only denial of fair trial, makes him an absolute victim of law.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://blogs.tribune.com.pk/story/20761/give-shakeel-afridi-a-fair-trial/ | title=Give Shakeel Afridi a Fair Trial | date=9 March 2014 | agency=Express Tribune | accessdate=9 March 2014}}</ref>
==Sentencing== On 28 May 2012, Prime Minister [[Yousaf Raza Gillani]] said according to the law in Pakistan Afridi has the right to defend himself and should be granted access to higher courts.<ref>[http://www.thenews.com.pk/NewsDetail.aspx?ID=51272 Dr Shakil Afridi has the right to defend himself: PM Gilani] The News International, 29 May 2012</ref>
On 30 May 2012, Afridi was sentenced to 33 years in prison for aiding banned militant group [[Lashkar-e-Islam]] and not for his links to the CIA, as officials had said earlier, according to a court document.<ref>[http://www.geo.tv/GeoDetail.aspx?ID=51824 Dr Shakil Afridi jailed for ties with Lashkar-e-Islam: court] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120601083213/http://www.geo.tv/GeoDetail.aspx?ID=51824# |date=1 June 2012 }} Geo News Pakistan, 30 May 2012</ref>
The court sentenced Afridi under the [[Frontier Crimes Regulations|Frontier Crimes Regulation, 1901]] a colonial era law. According to the verdict, Afridi would serve 33 years in prison and has to pay Rs. 230,000 as a fine. He was initially detained at the Apbara headquarters of the ISI in Islamabad before being moved to a Peshawar Central Jail in May 2012.<ref name="foxnews20120910"/><ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2012/05/201253015503713861.html "'Bin Laden doctor' jailed for 'fighter links'."] ''Al Jazeera'', 30 May 2012.</ref>
On 1 June 2012, Afridi's lawyers appealed his conviction.<ref>[http://www.geo.tv/GeoDetail.aspx?ID=52098 Lawyers appeal Dr Shakil Afridi's conviction] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605013556/http://www.geo.tv/GeoDetail.aspx?ID=52098# |date=5 June 2012 }}, Geo News, 1 June 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-7-111910-Dr-Shakil-Afridi-challenges-conviction-in-FCR-Commissioner-court Dr Shakil Afridi challenges conviction in FCR Commissioner court], The News, 2 June 2012</ref>
On 29 August 2013, senior Pakistani judicial official Sahibzada Mohammad Anis issued a ruling that overturned Afridi's sentence and ordered him a retrial. This was due to the decision that the original person who sentenced the doctor was not authorised to hear the case.<ref name="Fox News"/>
In mid-November 2013, the Reuters news agency reported that he had just been charged with murder in regard to the death, eight years earlier, of a patient he had treated.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pakistani doctor who helped U.S. find bin Laden charged with murder|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/11/22/us-pakistan-afridi-murder-idUSBRE9AL0F720131122|accessdate=22 November 2013 | work=Reuters|date=22 November 2013}}</ref> In March 2015, Samiullah Khan Afridi, Afridi's former lawyer, was shot dead in Peshawar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/03/lawyer-bin-laden-hunt-doctor-killed-150317162119865.html|title=Ex-lawyer of 'Bin Laden hunt' doctor killed in Pakistan|work=aljazeera.com}}</ref> A Pakistani Taliban faction named Jamaatul Ahrar claimed responsibility for his murder.<ref>{{cite web|date=17 March 2015|title=Taliban Faction Kills Lawyer|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/18/world/asia/taliban-faction-kills-lawyer.html?contentCollection=world&action=click&module=NextInCollection&region=Footer&pgtype=article|work=New York Times|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref>
In May 2018, Afridi was moved from prison to a 'safer location' by [[Pakistani intelligence community|Pakistani intelligence]] officials.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1404218|title=Dr Shakil Afridi moved from prison 'to safer location'|last=AFP|date=2018-04-27|work=DAWN.COM|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Hunger strike and current condition== In late November 2012 Pakistani news provider, ''The Express Tribune'', reported that Afridi had gone on a hunger strike protesting his prison conditions in the Peshawar jail. News also reported that regarding his treatment the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] had "made their views well known to Pakistan and the public at large".<ref name="Tribune PK">{{cite news|author=Huma Imtiaz|date=30 November 2012|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/473012/in-wake-of-shakil-afridis-hunger-strike-us-reiterates-calls-for-his-release/|title=In wake of Shakil Afridi's hunger strike, US reiterates calls for his release |newspaper=The Express Tribune|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> In September 2012, Dominic Di-Natale, an Islamabad-based correspondent and Sib Kaifee, a producer/reporter for Fox News claimed that they had interviewed Afridi by phone from inside the jail and spoke to him thrice between five and 45 minutes. Two prison guards were arrested and a senior prison official was sacked for allegedly providing Afridi with cell phones.
He is isolated from the general population.<ref name="Gannon">{{cite news |first=Kathy |last=Gannon |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/doctor-who-aided-hunt-for-bin-laden-languishes-forgotten/2018/01/22/f41ab6bc-ff3a-11e7-86b9-8908743c79dd_story.html |title=Doctor who aided hunt for bin Laden languishes, forgotten |publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]'' |date=January 22, 2018 |first2=Riaz |last2=Khan |first3=Matthew |last3=Lee}}</ref>
==Reactions to arrest and sentencing== ===U.S. response=== The [[United States Secretary of Defense|U.S. Secretary of Defense]], who was then CIA Chief [[Leon Panetta]], has confirmed the role of Afridi in ascertaining the whereabouts of bin Laden inside the compound in Abbottabad. U.S. Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] has said that Pakistan has no justification for holding Afridi.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/article-37643-No-justification-to-detain-Dr-Shakil--|title=No justification to detain Dr Shakil|date=1 March 2012|newspaper=The News International, Pakistan}}</ref> The U.S. Representative for the 48th District of California, [[Dana Rohrabacher]] asked President [[Barack Obama]] to intercede on Afridi's behalf,<ref>{{cite web|date=29 February 2012|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/us-congressman-to-obama-dont-abandon-doctor-who-helped-cia/918164/|title=US Congressman to Obama: Don't abandon doctor who helped CIA|work=indianexpress.com|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> introduced two bills, H.R. 4069 to award a [[Congressional Gold Medal]] to Afridi<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opencongress.org/bill/112-h4069/comments|title=H.R.4069: To award a Congressional Gold Medal to Dr. Shakeel Afridi. - U.S. Congress - OpenCongress|work=opencongress.org}}</ref> and H.R. 3901 to declare Afridi a naturalised U.S. citizen.<ref>[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-112hr3901ih/pdf/BILLS-112hr3901ih.pdf H. R. 3901 For the relief of Dr. Shakeel Afridi.]</ref>
The [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] panel cut $33 million in aid to Pakistan over the conviction of Afridi: $1 million for each of the 33 years of Afridi's sentence.<ref>{{cite news|date=25 May 2012|title=Senate panel votes to cut $33M in Pakistan aid over bin Laden doctor's conviction|url=http://nbcpolitics.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/05/25/11873708-senate-panel-votes-to-cut-33m-in-pakistan-aid-over-bin-laden-doctors-conviction?lite|work=NBC News|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref>
U.S. authorities said that before his arrest, Afridi turned down an opportunity to leave his country and resettle overseas with his family.<ref>{{cite web|date=30 May 2012|title=Afridi in OBL hunt rejected US escape: officials|url=http://www.geo.tv/GeoDetail.aspx?ID=51703|work=Geo News Pakistan|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> On 31 May 2012, U.S. authorities said that they sought clarification from Pakistan on the issue of Afridi's sentence.<ref>{{cite web|date=31 May 2012|title=US seeks clarity on Dr Afridi reports|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/NewsDetail.aspx?ID=51878|work=The News International|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref>
In September 2012, the U.S. State Department said that they would consider a prisoner exchange for [[Aafia Siddiqui]] but Pakistan refused the deal.
In May 2015 [[Seymour Hersh]] identified Afridi has been [[scapegoating|scapegoated]] by the CIA and the U.S. State Department of the [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. Government]].
In June 2011, it was reported in ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and all over the Pakistani press that [[Amer Aziz|Amir Aziz]] had been held for questioning in Pakistan; he was, it was said, a CIA informant who had been spying on the comings and goings at the bin Laden compound. Aziz was released, but the retired official said that U.S. intelligence was unable to learn who leaked the highly classified information about his involvement with the mission. Officials in Washington decided they "could not take a chance that Aziz's role in obtaining bin Laden's DNA also would become known". A [[sacrificial lamb]] was needed, and the one chosen was Afridi, a 48-year-old Pakistani doctor and sometime CIA asset, who had been arrested by the Pakistanis in late May and accused of assisting the agency. "We went to the Pakistanis and said go after Afridi", the retired official said. "We had to cover the whole issue of how we got the DNA." It was soon reported that the CIA had organised a fake vaccination programme in Abbottabad with Afridi's help in a failed attempt to obtain bin Laden's DNA. Afridi's legitimate medical operation was run independently of local health authorities, was well financed and offered free vaccinations against [[hepatitis B]]. Posters advertising the programme were displayed throughout the area. Afridi was later accused of treason and sentenced to 33 years in prison because of his ties to an extremist. News of the CIA-sponsored programme created widespread anger in Pakistan, and led to the cancellation of other international vaccination programmes that were now seen as cover for American spying.
The retired official said that Afridi had been recruited long before the bin Laden mission as part of a separate intelligence effort to get information about suspected terrorists in Abbottabad and the surrounding area. "The plan was to use vaccinations as a way to get the blood of terrorism suspects in the villages." Afridi made no attempt to obtain DNA from the residents of the bin Laden compound. The report that he did so was a hurriedly put together "CIA cover story creating 'facts'" in a clumsy attempt to protect Aziz and his real mission. "Now we have the consequences", the retired official said. "A great [[Humanitarianism|humanitarian]] project to do something meaningful for the [[peasant]]s has been compromised as a [[Cynicism (contemporary)|cynical]] [[hoax]]." Afridi's conviction was overturned, but he remains in prison on a murder charge.<ref name = "LRB OBL">{{Cite journal | last = Hersh | first = Seymour | year = 2015 | title = The Killing of Osama bin Laden | url = http://www.lrb.co.uk/v37/n10/seymour-m-hersh/the-killing-of-osama-bin-laden | journal = London Review of Books | volume = 37 | number = 10 | pages = 3–12 | accessdate = 21 May 2015 }}</ref>
[[James W. Curran|James Curran]], dean of the [[Rollins School of Public Health]] at [[Emory University]], stated that spy agencies should consider the consequences of using health care institutions for their own ends: "It is always important to disassociate public health missions from wartime or spy missions that could disrupt the bonds of community trust".<ref>[https://firstlook.org/theintercept/2015/05/21/nsa-plan-find-osama-bin-laden-infiltrating-medical-supply-chain/ The NSA Plan to Find Bin Laden by Hiding Tracking Devices in Medical Supplies], [[The Intercept]], 21 May 2015</ref>
===Protest by aid groups=== Humanitarian organisations, including [[Médecins Sans Frontières]], protested the use of a medical charity for espionage purposes believing it would cause suspicion of such organisations in the future and endanger personnel working on such projects claiming 'threatened immunisation work around the world'.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jul/14/cia-fake-vaccination-medecins-frontieres |title=CIA's fake vaccination programme criticised by Médecins Sans Frontières |date=14 July 2011 |author=Saeed Shah |work=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2012/03/02/140671/aid-groups-protest-to-cia-over.html#storylink=cpy|title=Aid groups protest to CIA over bin Laden scheme|work=McClatchy DC}}</ref>
May 2012 the ''Access to Justice Through Legal Aid and Welfare Organisation Peshawar'' named a panel of lawyers to defend Dr Afridi in his appeal against his conviction.<ref>[http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-13-14999-NGO-names-lawyers-panel-to-defend-Dr-Shakil-Afridi NGO names lawyers' panel to defend Dr Shakil Afridi] The News International, 30 May 2012</ref>
===Lashkar-e-Islam reaction=== On 31 May 2012, [[Lashkar-e-Islam]] militants said they had nothing to do with Afridi and would kill him if given the chance. A commander in the militant organisation told the [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]], "We have no link to such a shameless man. If we see him, we'll chew him alive."
The court said Afridi paid two million rupees (US$21,000) to Lashkar-e-Islam and helped to provide medical assistance to militant commanders in Khyber. But the commander said the $21,000 was a fine imposed for over-charging patients. "Afridi and his fellow doctor were fleecing tribesmen, giving them fake medicines and doing fake surgeries. We had a lot of complaints against them and imposed a fine of two million rupees on them," he said. Local residents have also told AFP that [[Mangal Bagh]] fined Afridi for performing "unnecessary surgeries and over-charging" patients at his private clinic in the town of [[Bara, FATA|Bara]].<ref name="afp20120531">{{cite news | url=http://www.geo.tv/GeoDetail.aspx?ID=51914 | title=Militants deny link with Dr Shakil Afridi | work=www.geo.tv | date=31 May 2012 | agency=AFP | accessdate=5 June 2012}}</ref>
==See also== * [[CIA activities in Pakistan]] * [[Jamrud]], located in the [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas]], where the hospital was that Afridi was the chief surgeon of
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.interaction.org/document/interaction-letter-cia InterAction Letter to the CIA criticizing his use of a medical charity for espionage purposes.] *[https://www.npr.org/2011/10/07/141144760/pakistani-doctor-who-helped-cia-may-face-treason-trial Pakistan Doctor, Who Helped CIA, Accused Of Treason], NPR, 2011-10-07 *[http://www.thenews.com.pk/ImportantEvents.aspx?ID=77&title=%C2%A0Dr-Shakil-Afridi Dr Shakeel Afridi, who helped US to kill Osama], The News, 2012-05-28 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120531022545/http://www.geo.tv/GeoDetail.aspx?ID=51422 Dr Shakil Afridi awarded unilateral sentence: brother], Geo News Pakistan, 28 May 2012 *[http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-2-110982-33-year-sentence-on-treason-charges-Lawyers-panel-NGO-to-defend-Dr-Shakeel-Afridi 33-year sentence on treason charges Lawyers' panel, NGO to defend Dr Shakeel Afridi], The News International, 28 May 2012 *[http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-6-111682-Divergent-Pak-US-perceptions-on-Shakil-Afridi Divergent Pak-US perceptions on Shakil Afridi ], The News International, 1 June 2012 *[http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-9-112572-Twists-in-the-Afridi-case Twists in the Afridi case], The News International, 5 June 2012

{{refimprove|date=July 2017}} [[File:ChaumetSimone 1953 Kabylie (alone).jpg|thumb|Simone Chaumet (1953)]] '''Simone Tanner Chaumet''' (1916 - 25 May 1962)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://db.yadvashem.org/righteous/righteousName.html?language=en&itemId=7009257|title=Chaumet Simone|last=|first=|date=|website=Yad Vashem|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-07-24}}</ref> was a [[French people|French]] peace activist and was a volunteer for [[Service Civil International|SCI (Service Civil International)]] between 1943 and 1945 in [[France]] and between 1951 and 1956 in [[Algeria]]. She was honoured as ''[[Righteous Among the Nations]]'' by the [[State of Israel]] in 2011 for her actions to save [[Jewish]] children during [[World War II|the Second World War]].
==Early life == Chaumet was born during the 1914-1918 war, but her exact birth date and place are not known. She never knew her father. This situation affected her susceptibility in her youth years. Her mother got married again. Her step-father who was a lovely man took his wife and two daughters to Cannes to live there. The relationship between Chaumet and her step-father was intense. In 1942, she joined the CLAJ (Club loisirs action jeunesse) with her friend Jamy Bissérier and in 1943 she became the secretary of CLAJ which was associated with "Amitiés Chrétienne" in Col du Fanget in the [[French Alps]]. While she was working there, she saved the life of [[Jewish history|Jewish]] children (François Gelbert, Maurice and Charles Wrobel, Gilbert and Maxime Allouche) during [[World War II|the Second World War]] in [[France]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://archives.sci.ngo/news/116/70/SCI-volunteer-recognized-as-Righteous-among-the-Nations.html|title=Service Civil International - Archives of Service Civil International|last=Rodriguez|first=Philipp|website=archives.sci.ngo|access-date=2017-07-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://yadvashem-france.org/les-justes-parmi-les-nations/les-justes-de-france/dossier-11693/|title={{!}} Le comité Français pour Yad Vashem|website=yadvashem-france.org|language=fr|access-date=2017-07-24}}</ref>
== Chaumet and SCI (Service Civil International) == SCI was very important for Chaumet and her life. She paid attention to SCI's calls and she decided to be a volunteer on behalf of SCI. She was very active in [[France]] between 1945 and 1950 for this group and she continued to be a long-term volunteer in [[Algeria]] between 1951 and 1956. She married with the SCI secretary Emile Tanner.<ref name=":0" /> Chaumet who explored the useful aspects of education when she was a volunteer for SCI, set up a school in [[Bouzaréah|Bouzareah]]. She wanted to help the people who didn't know how to read and write and the children who needed education.<ref name=":0" />
==Death and Commemoration == She was murdered on 25 May 1962 in the struggle of the [[Algerian War|Algerian Independence war.]] A commemorative plaque was installed on the Col du Fanget on 7 May 2005. The children; François Gelbert, Gilbert and Maxime Allouche that Chaumet saved their lives, attended the commemoration to honour her. Also, she was commemorated in [[Israel]] as she saved the lives of [[Jews|Jewish]] children during [[World War II|WWII]] in [[France]]. Finally, she was honoured on 24 October 2011 as [[Righteous Among the Nations|Righteous among the Nations]] in the ''Salle des Fêtes de la Mairie du 6e arrondissment'', 78 rue Bonaparte, in [[Paris]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ajpn.org/juste-Simone-Chaumet-3183.html|title=Simone-Chaumet|last=France|first=ajpn, Hellen Kaufmann, Bernard Lhoumeau, Bordeaux, Aquitaine,|website=www.ajpn.org|access-date=2017-07-24}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> Tanner-Chaumet is listed on plate 10 of the [[Algerian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] ''Wall of the Missing'' of people lost during wars in Algeria.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Wall of the Missing List|url=http://www.cerclealgerianiste.fr/index.php/le-memorial-des-disparus/la-liste-du-mur-des-disparus|website=Cercle Algérianiste|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref>

revision.text:
'''Tangent''' is a social networking organisation for ladies aged over 45, primarily intended for former members of [[Ladies Circle]]. It is part of the Round Table Family of clubs, together with [[Round Table (club)]], [[Ladies Circle]] and [[41 Club]].
Ladies who are either (a) the wife or partner of a former member of Round Table or (b) a former member of Ladies Circle are eligible to join Tangent. (From 2009 some Tangent clubs have open membership and accept women who were not previously members of Ladies Circle).
'''Round Table''' itself was formed in 1927, a social networking and community group exclusively for men aged under 40. Within three years, their wives had formed their own group, Ladies Circle. Like Round Table, Ladies Circle was specifically intended for younger ladies, and so was only open to under 40s. In 1953, former members of Bournemouth Ladies Circle formed their own group, Tangent.
In the 1990s, Ladies Circle opened up membership to non wives/female partners of Tablers/ ex Tablers
Like the three other clubs in the movement, there are various Tangent clubs in towns and cities across the UK, and overseas.
Recently, some Tangent clubs have opened their doors to non ex Circlers.
Tangent clubs are affiliated to the National Association of Tangent Clubs (NATC). The members of each club will usually meet monthly, and organise various social events, and also activities to raise funds for charity or to support the community. Clubs will often hold Friendship or Fellowship evenings and invite other clubs in the neighbourhood to attend. Members of different clubs also have the opportunity to meet at a number of Regional Lunches held throughout the year.
A National AGM is held in April each year at a different venue. The members of the National Executive are elected at this meeting, and various proposals will be debated and voted on.
The Club motto is "Let Friendship Continue".
==External links== * [http://www.tangentclubs.org/ National Association of Tangent Clubs] * [http://www.roundtable.co.uk/the-clubs/ The Round Table Family] * [http://www.ladies-circle.org.uk/ The National Association of Ladies Circles of Great Britain and Ireland] * [http://www.roundtable.co.uk Round Table home]
==References== *{{Citation |last=Robinson |first=Jean |publication-date=1974 |title=CIRCLE THE STORY OF N.A.L.C. 1936-1974 |publication-place=Keighley |publisher=NALC}} *{{Citation |last=Barty-King |first=Hugh |publication-date=1977 |title=Round Table: The Search for Fellowship |publication-place=London |publisher=Heinemann}} *{{Citation |last=Creasey |first=John |publication-date=1952 |title=Round Table: the First Twenty-Five Years of the Round Table Movement |publication-place=Norwich |publisher=Jarrold & Sons}}

page.title: Timeline of women's sports in the United States

revision.text:
This is a timeline of '''[[women's sports]] in the United States.''' [[File:Drawing by Marguerite Martyn of women athlete prototypes from 1600 to 1911.jpg|thumb|650px|center|
Impressions of women athletes in the United States from 1600
as drawn in 1911 by artist and reporter [[Marguerite Martyn]]]]
{{TOC right}} == 1700s == 1780 - Three days of [[horse racing]] at the track in [[Hempstead Plains]], [[Long Island]], included an event for women riders.{{cite web|url=http://www.northnet.org/stlawrenceaauw/timeline.htm |title=History of Women in Sports Timeline - Part 1- to 1899 |publisher=northnet.org |accessdate=2014-01-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527131109/http://www.northnet.org/stlawrenceaauw/timeline.htm |archivedate=2014-05-27 |df= }} == 1800s == 1864 - The Park Place Croquet Club of Brooklyn organized with 25 members. [[Croquet]] is probably the first game played by both women and men in America. 1866 - [[Vassar College]] fielded the first two women's amateur baseball teams. 1874 - [[Mary Ewing Outerbridge]] of Staten Island introduced tennis to the United States. She purchased tennis equipment in Bermuda (and had trouble getting it through Customs) and used it to set up the first US tennis court at the Staten Island Cricket and Baseball Club that spring. 1875 - The "Blondes" and "Brunettes" played their first match in Springfield, Illinois on Sept. 11. Newspapers heralded the event as the "first game of baseball ever played in public for gate money between feminine ball-tossers." 1875 - [[Wellesley College]] opened with a gymnasium for exercising and a lake for ice skating and the first rowing program for women. 1876 - Nell Saunders defeated Rose Harland in the first United States women's boxing match, receiving a silver butter dish as her prize. 1882 - At the YWCA in Boston, the first athletic games for women were held. 1887 - [[Ellen Hansell]] was crowned the first Women's Singles tennis champion at the U.S. Open. 1889 - [[Bertha Townsend]] and [[Margarette Ballard]], both of the United States, won the first Women's Doubles at the U.S. Open. 1889 - The first women's six-day bicycle race ended at [[Madison Square Garden]] in New York City. 1894 - The first ladies golf tournament was held on the 7-hole Morristown, NJ course on Oct 17 – 1894. Miss Hollard A. Ford won with a 97 scored on the double-7, 14 strokes under her nearest rival. 1895 - The first Women's Amateur Golf championship was contested among 13 golfers at the [[Meadow Brook Golf Club|Meadow Brook Club]], Hempstead, N.Y., on Nov. 9. The match was won by Mrs. Charles S. Brown with a 132 and the runner-up is Nellie Sargent. 1895 - The first organized athletics meeting was generally recognized as the "Field Day" at Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY, on Nov. 9. A group of "nimble, supple and vivacious girls" engaged in running and jumping events despite bad weather. 1895 - The first women's softball team was formed at Chicago's [[West Division High School]]. They did not have a coach for competitive play until 1899. 1896 - The first 6-day bicycle race for women started on Jan 6 at Madison Square Garden in NYC. 1896 - The first women's intercollegiate basketball championship was played between Stanford and the University of California at Berkeley. Stanford won 2-1 on April 4 before a crowd of 700 women. 1898 - Lizzie Arlington became the first woman to sign a professional baseball contract, appearing in her first professional game pitching for the Philadelphia Reserves. == 1900s == === 1900s === 1900 - The Olympics first allowed women. [[Margaret Abbott]] won a gold medal in golf; she was the first American woman to take first place in an Olympic event.{{cite web|url=http://gtresearchnews.gatech.edu/reshor/rh-win96/timeline.htm |title=Olympic Timeline |publisher=Gtresearchnews.gatech.edu |date=1996-05-28 |accessdate=2014-02-05}} 1901- Constance M.K, at Harvard University, introduced [[field hockey]] to the women of the United States.{{cite web|url=http://faculty.elmira.edu/dmaluso/sports/timeline/fieldhockey.html |title=Timeline of Women in Sports |publisher=Faculty.elmira.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-05}} 1909 - [[Alice Huyler Ramsey]] became the first woman to drive across the United States.{{cite journal |first=Marina Koestler |last=Ruben |title=Alice Ramsey's Historic Cross-Country Drive |url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/specialsections/womens-history/The-Centennial-of-Alice-Ramseys-Drive.html |quote=In 1909, 22-year-old Alice Ramsey made history as the first woman to drive across the United States ... |journal= [[Smithsonian (magazine)|Smithsonian]] |publisher= [[Smithsonian Institution]] |date= June 5, 2009 |accessdate= March 9, 2010 }} === 1910s === 1911 - [[Helene Britton]] was the first woman to own a major league team. She was the head director of the St. Louis Cardinals from 1911 to 1917.{{cite web|url=http://faculty.elmira.edu/dmaluso/sports/timeline/softball.html|title=Timeline of Women in Sports|publisher=faculty.elmira.edu|accessdate=2014-01-19}} 1914 - Women's basketball rules changed to allow half-court play. 1916 — The [[Women's International Bowling Congress]], the all-female counterpart to the 1895-founded all-male [[American Bowling Congress]] for the [[tenpin bowling]] sport is established. === 1920s === 1922 - The U.S. Field Hockey Association, the National Governing Body for field hockey in the United States, was established. 1923 - The Amateur Athletic Union (AAU) sponsored [[1923 USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships|the first national championships for women in track and field]] 1924 - The Amateur Athletic Union (AAU) held the first national basketball tournament for women with six teams.{{cite web|url=http://faculty.elmira.edu/dmaluso/sports/timeline/basketball.html |title=Timeline of Women in Sports |publisher=Faculty.elmira.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-05}} 1926 - The [[Amateur Athletic Union]] sponsored the first-ever national women's basketball championship.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/pov/trueheartedvixens/timeline.php|title=Timeline: A Brief History of Women's Team Sports in America | True-Hearted Vixens | POV | PBS|publisher=pbs.org|accessdate=2014-01-19}} 1926 - New York City native [[Gertrude Ederle]] became the first woman to swim the English Channel, which she did in fourteen hours, thirty-one minutes, beating the best time to date.{{cite web|url=http://faculty.elmira.edu/dmaluso/sports/timeline/swimming.html |title=Timeline of Women in Sports |publisher=Faculty.elmira.edu |date=1950-03-01 |accessdate=2014-02-05}} === 1930s === 1931 - Judge [[Kenesaw Mountain Landis]] banned women from professional baseball. He felt that he needed to after a seventeen-year-old pitcher Virne Beatrice “Jackie” Mitchell struck out Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig in an exhibition game. 1932 - [[Babe Didrikson]] was named Associate Press Woman Athlete of the Year for track and field after she scored enough points at the AAU national meet to win the team championship by herself. She scored thirty points, eight points more than the whole second place team earned.{{cite web|url=http://faculty.elmira.edu/dmaluso/sports/timeline/track.html |title=Timeline of Women in Sports |publisher=Faculty.elmira.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-05}} 1936 - The [[All American Red Heads Team]], a barnstorming troupe similar to the Bloomer Girls, was formed. It is generally regarded as the first women's professional basketball team. 1936 - [[Ruth Hughes Aarons]] was the first American that won the world singles table tennis championship.{{cite web|url=http://faculty.elmira.edu/dmaluso/sports/timeline/tennis.html |title=Timeline of Women in Sports |publisher=Faculty.elmira.edu |date=1933-06-24 |accessdate=2014-02-05}} 1937 - Grace Hudowalski was the ninth person and first woman to climb all 46 of the [[Adirondack High Peaks]].{{cite web|url=http://www.syracuse.com/outdoors/index.ssf/2014/06/adirondack_mountain_renamed_after_first_woman_to_scale_all_46_high_peaks.html|title=Adirondack mountain renamed after first woman to scale all 46 High Peaks | syracuse.com|publisher=syracuse.com|accessdate=2014-07-14}}{{cite web |title=Tribute to Grace Hudowalski 46er #9 |publisher=Adirondack Forum |date=March 14, 2004 |archivedate=2010-01-16 |url=http://www.adkforum.com/archive/index.php?t-519.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100116033946/http://adkforum.com/showthread.php?t=519 |accessdate=2011-05-16}}{{cite web |title=Grace Peak Update 11-23-08 |date=November 23, 2008 |publisher=Views From The Top |url=http://www.viewsfromthetop.com/forums/showthread.php?t=26413 |accessdate=2011-05-16}} === 1940s === 1943 - The All-American Girls Softball League was formed under [[Chicago White Sox]] owner Philip Wrigley. The League gradually transformed into the [[All-American Girls Professional Baseball League]]. 1949 - [[Marcenia Lyle Alberga]] was the first woman to play a full season in a professional men’s baseball league. 1949 - [[Sara Christian]] became the first female [[NASCAR]] driver, racing in the inaugural NASCAR race at [[Charlotte Speedway]], even though she had [[Bob Flock]] finish the race.{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race?id=1949-01&series=W |title=1949-01 |publisher=Racing-Reference.info |date=1949-06-19 |accessdate=2012-04-18}} In the second official race at [[Daytona Beach and Road Course]], also in 1949, Christian was joined by [[Ethel Mobley]] and [[Louise Smith]], with Mobley finishing ahead of the 3, at 11th.{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race?id=1949-02&series=W |title=1949-02 |publisher=Racing-Reference.info |date=1949-07-10 |accessdate=2012-04-18}} === 1950s === 1950 - Kathryn Johnston, only twelve years old, was the first girl to play [[Little League Baseball]]. She played for the King’s Dairy team in Corning, NY.{{cite web|url=http://tubbyjohnston.com/|title=Tubby Johnston|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826113415/http://tubbyjohnston.com/|archivedate=26 August 2014|df=}} Kathryn played at first base for the season, but then had to stop because of her age (she turned 13.) After that, a rule prohibited girls from playing in Little League; this was in force until 1974.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/08/20/sports/baseball-one-more-pitch-for-first-girl-in-little-league.html | work=The New York Times | first=Neil | last=Amdur | title=BASEBALL; One More Pitch for First Girl in Little League | date=2001-08-20}} 1951 - Betty Chapman was the first African American professional softball player. 1952 - [[Patricia McCormick (bullfighter)|Patricia McCormick]] began bullfighting as a professional ''Matadora'' in January 1952, and was the first American to do so.{{cite news|last1=Mealer|first1=Bryan|title=Patricia McCormick, Bullfighter Who Defied Convention, Is Dead at 83|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/07/us/patricia-mccormick-a-pioneer-in-the-bullfighting-arena-dies-at-83.html?_r=0|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=April 13, 2013}} 1953 – The USA women’s basketball team won the gold in the first international basketball game. 1953 - [[Toni Stone]], also known by her married name Marcenia Lyle Alberga, was the first of three women to play [[Negro league baseball]], and thus the first woman to play as a regular on an American big-league professional baseball team.{{cite news|last=Mcg |first=Robert |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/11/10/sports/toni-stone-75-first-woman-to-play-big-league-baseball.html |title=Toni Stone, 75, First Woman To Play Big-League Baseball |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=1996-11-10 |accessdate=2015-04-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aaregistry.org/historic_events/view/black-woman-pro-baseball-toni-stone|title=THE Black woman of pro baseball, Toni Stone|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2014}} 1954 - The All-American Girls Professional Baseball League played its last season. 1955 - The first LPGA championship was held.{{cite web|url=http://faculty.elmira.edu/dmaluso/sports/timeline/golf.html |title=Timeline of Women in Sports |publisher=Faculty.elmira.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-05}} 1959 - [[Arlene Pieper]] became the first woman to officially finish a marathon in the United States when she finished the [[Pikes Peak Marathon]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pikespeakmarathon.org/mystique.htm|title=First woman to run marathon in US - PPM|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.arlenepieper.com/|title=Home|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2014}} === 1960s === 1960 - [[Mary McGee]] earns a [[Fédération Internationale de Motocyclisme|FIM]] license and becomes the first official female motorcycle racer in the United States. 1961 - The [[USBC Queens|WIBC Queens]] all-female tenpin bowling tournament is first established. 1966 - The first intercollegiate women's basketball tournament was played in Pennsylvania. 1966 - [[Roberta Louise "Bobbi" Gibb]] was the first woman to run the entire [[Boston Marathon]].{{cite web|url=http://www.baa.org/races/boston-marathon/boston-marathon-history.aspx |title=B.A.A.: Boston Marathon History |publisher= |accessdate=6 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307073949/http://www.baa.org/races/boston-marathon/boston-marathon-history.aspx |archivedate=March 7, 2012 }} 1967 - [[Kathrine Switzer]] was the first woman to run the Boston Marathon as a numbered entry.{{cite web|url=http://kathrineswitzer.com/about-kathrine/kathrines-short-bio/|title=Kathrine Switzer Marathon Woman - Author. Activist. Athlete.|publisher=kathrineswitzer.com|accessdate=2014-01-19}} 1969 - Barbara Jo Rubin became the first female jockey to win a race in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://m.wbaltv.com/sports/retired-female-jockeys-to-cheer-on-potential-historymaker/20175750 |title=Retired female jockeys to cheer on potential history-maker | Sports - Home |publisher=M.wbaltv.com |date=2013-05-16 |accessdate=2015-04-16}} === 1970s === 1970 - [[Mary Jo Peppler]] of the United States was voted the most outstanding volleyball player in the world at the International Games in Bulgaria.{{cite web|url=http://faculty.elmira.edu/dmaluso/sports/timeline/volleyball.html |title=Timeline of Women in Sports |publisher=Faculty.elmira.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-02-05}} 1971 - Cheryl White, an American, became the first black female jockey.{{cite web|url=http://www.horse-races.net/library/article-cherylwhite.htm |title=Jockey Cheryl White, An American Missed |publisher=Horse-races.net |date= |accessdate=2015-04-16}} 1971 - The [American] [[National Girls and Women in Sports Day]] (NGWSD) is an annual day of observance held during the first week of February to acknowledge the accomplishments of female athletes, recognize the influence of sports participation for women and girls, and honor the progress and continuing struggle for equality for women in sports.{{cite web|title=About|url=http://ngwsd.org/about/|publisher=National Girls & Women in Sports Day|accessdate=21 February 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Glass|first1=Alana|title=How Celebrating National Girls And Women In Sports Day Can Unlock The C-Suite|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alanaglass/2017/01/31/how-celebrating-national-girls-and-women-in-sports-day-can-unlock-the-c-suite/#383b41243bd2|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=21 February 2017|date=31 January 2017}} Each year since its inception in 1987, the [[United States Congress]] recognizes women's contributions to sports and society on a day during the first week of February.{{cite web|last1=McCarthy|first1=Karen|title=13TH Annual National Girls and Women in Sports Day|url=https://www.congress.gov/congressional-record/1999/2/2/extensions-of-remarks-section/article/E116-2|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=21 February 2017|date=February 2, 1999}} 1988 - San Antonio Stars' and future Spurs assistant Becky Hammon was born to coach - ESPN|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=6 October 2014}} 2014 - Catherine “Cat” Conti became the first female referee in Big 12 football history.{{cite web|url=http://www.kansan.com/sports/first-female-ref-in-big-football-history-earns-kansas-respect/article_6e701d4e-39eb-11e4-80ed-d71c0f214ae6.html|title=First female ref in Big 12 football history earns Kansas’ respect|work=The University Daily Kansan|accessdate=6 October 2014}} 2014 - 9-year-old Kelly Xu |publisher=FOX Sports |date=2014-04-06 |accessdate=2015-04-12}}{{cite news|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2014/04/kelly-xu-augusta-national-masters |title=Meet 9-year-old Kelly Xu, the first female champion at Augusta National | For The Win |publisher=Ftw.usatoday.com |date= |accessdate=2015-04-12}} [[File:The United States Women's Soccer Team Ticker-Tape Parade New York City (19397144590).jpg|240px|thumb|right|United States women's national soccer team players at the Ticker Tape Parade, New York City, July 10, 2015]] 2015 - The winning [[United States women's national soccer team]] defeated former champions [[Japan women's national football team|Japan]] 5–2 in the [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup Final]], led by a [[hat trick]] by [[Carli Lloyd]].{{cite web|last1=Robinson|first1=Joanna|title=WATCH U.S. SOCCER PLAYER CARLI LLOYD MAKE WORLD CUP HISTORY WITH RECORD-BREAKING HAT TRICK|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2015/07/carli-lloyd-world-cup-hat-trick-record-breaking|publisher=Vanity Fair|accessdate=21 February 2017|date=July 5, 2015}} The team was honored with a historic [[ticker tape parade]] in New York City, marking the first time a women's sports team was celebrated in the city's [[Canyon of Heroes]].{{cite web|title=Women's Soccer Team Earns Ticker-Tape Parade In NYC — And A Return To No. 1|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/07/10/421731939/ticker-tape-parade-in-nyc-for-women-s-soccer-team-and-a-return-to-no-1|publisher=NPR|accessdate=21 February 2017|date=July 10, 2015}} 2015 -
